questions.question: For 2024, the Social Security wage base (maximum earnings subject to Social Security tax) is:
questions.explanation: The 2024 Social Security wage base is $168,600. Earnings above this amount are not subject to Social Security tax (6.2% employee/employer). Medicare tax (1.45%) has no wage base limit and applies to all wages. Additional Medicare tax (0.9%) applies above $200,000.
questions.tip: 2024 SS wage base = $168,600. Medicare = unlimited. Additional Medicare (0.9%) above $200K.

questions.question: The self-employment tax rate consists of:

options.B: 12.4% for Social Security plus 2.9% for Medicare

questions.explanation: Self-employment tax combines both employer and employee portions: 12.4% Social Security (up to the wage base) plus 2.9% Medicare, totaling 15.3%. Self-employed individuals deduct half of SE tax as an adjustment to income. Additional Medicare tax (0.9%) applies above $200,000.
questions.tip: SE tax = 15.3% (12.4% SS + 2.9% Medicare). Deduct half for AGI. Additional 0.9% Medicare above $200K.

questions.question: The primary IRS test for determining employee vs. independent contractor status focuses on:

options.A: The amount paid to the worker
options.B: The degree of control the employer has over how work is performed
options.C: Whether the worker has other clients
options.D: The length of the working relationship

questions.explanation: The IRS examines the degree of control and independence in the relationship using factors in three categories: behavioral control (how work is done), financial control (business aspects), and type of relationship (contracts, benefits, permanence). Control is the key factor.
questions.tip: Employee vs. contractor = control test. Behavioral, financial, and relationship factors. More control = employee.

questions.question: The Federal Unemployment Tax Act (FUTA) tax is paid by:

options.B: Employers only

questions.explanation: FUTA is paid entirely by employers - employees do not contribute. The gross rate is 6.0% on the first $7,000 of each employee's wages. Employers receive a credit (up to 5.4%) for state unemployment taxes paid, resulting in an effective rate of 0.6% for most employers.
questions.tip: FUTA = employer only. 6.0% on first $7,000. Usually 0.6% after state credit.

questions.question: Backup withholding at a rate of 24% applies when:

options.A: An employee claims too many exemptions
options.B: A payee fails to provide a valid taxpayer identification number
options.C: The employer fails to file Form 941

questions.explanation: Backup withholding (24% rate) applies to certain payments (interest, dividends, nonemployee compensation) when the payee fails to provide a valid TIN, the IRS notifies the payer that the TIN is incorrect, or the payee is subject to backup withholding for prior underreporting.
questions.tip: Backup withholding = 24%. Triggered by missing/incorrect TIN or IRS notification.

questions.question: Form W-2 must be provided to employees by:

options.B: January 31

questions.explanation: Employers must provide Form W-2 to employees by January 31 following the calendar year. W-2s must also be filed with the Social Security Administration by January 31 (paper or electronic). Penalties apply for late or incorrect forms.
questions.tip: W-2 deadline: January 31 to employees and SSA. W-3 transmittal also due January 31.

questions.question: The Additional Medicare Tax of 0.9% applies to:

options.B: Wages and self-employment income exceeding $200,000 ($250,000 MFJ)

questions.explanation: The Additional Medicare Tax (0.9%) applies to wages, railroad retirement compensation, and self-employment income exceeding $200,000 ($250,000 MFJ, $125,000 MFS). Employers must withhold on wages over $200,000 regardless of filing status. There's no employer match for this tax.
questions.tip: Additional Medicare = 0.9% employee-only. Employer withholds above $200K. No employer match.

questions.question: Self-employment tax is calculated on:

options.B: 92.35% of net self-employment earnings
options.D: Net self-employment earnings minus all business deductions

questions.explanation: Self-employment tax is calculated on 92.35% of net self-employment earnings (net earnings × 0.9235). This reduction approximates the equivalent of the employer's share of FICA that reduces the employee's taxable wages. The result is then multiplied by 15.3%.
questions.tip: SE tax base = net SE earnings × 92.35%. Compensates for no employer portion reducing income.

questions.question: Employers are classified as monthly or semi-weekly depositors based on:

options.B: Employment taxes reported during a lookback period

questions.explanation: Deposit frequency is determined by total employment taxes reported during the lookback period (the 12-month period ending June 30 of the prior year). If taxes were $50,000 or less, the employer is a monthly depositor. Over $50,000 = semi-weekly depositor. $100,000 or more on any day = next-day deposit.
questions.tip: Lookback period determines schedule: ≤$50K = monthly, >$50K = semi-weekly. $100K+ any day = next day deposit.

questions.question: Section 530 relief protects employers from employment tax liability for misclassified workers if:

options.A: The workers agree to contractor status
options.B: The employer had a reasonable basis for the classification and consistently treated similar workers the same way
options.C: The misclassification was for less than $50,000

questions.explanation: Section 530 provides safe harbor relief if: (1) the employer had a reasonable basis for classification (prior audit, industry practice, IRS ruling, advice of counsel), (2) the employer filed all required 1099s, and (3) the employer consistently treated similar workers the same way.
questions.tip: Section 530 safe harbor: reasonable basis + filed 1099s + consistent treatment. Protects from back taxes.

questions.question: Which of the following fringe benefits is generally taxable to the employee?

options.B: Personal use of a company car
options.C: De minimis meals provided for employer convenience

questions.explanation: Personal use of a company car is a taxable fringe benefit. The value must be included in the employee's wages and is subject to income and employment taxes. Health insurance, certain meals, and qualified discounts are generally excludable from income.
questions.tip: Personal use of company car = taxable. Value included in W-2. Use IRS valuation methods.

questions.question: Form 941 (Employer's Quarterly Federal Tax Return) reports:

options.B: Quarterly wages, tips, federal income tax withheld, and FICA taxes

questions.explanation: Form 941 is filed quarterly and reports wages paid, tips reported, federal income tax withheld, and employer and employee Social Security and Medicare taxes. Small employers may file Form 944 annually instead if notified by the IRS.
questions.tip: Form 941 = quarterly employment tax return. Reports wages, withholding, and FICA. Due end of month after quarter.

questions.question: The trust fund recovery penalty (TFRP) applies to:

options.B: Willful failure to collect, account for, or pay over withheld income and FICA taxes

questions.explanation: The TFRP (100% penalty) applies to responsible persons who willfully fail to collect, account for, or pay over trust fund taxes (employee's portion of FICA and withheld income tax). This penalty can be assessed personally against officers, directors, and others with authority over tax matters.
questions.tip: TFRP = 100% personal liability on responsible persons. Applies to withheld taxes not paid over. Very serious penalty.

questions.question: Self-employment tax applies when net self-employment earnings are at least:
questions.explanation: Self-employment tax applies when net self-employment earnings are $400 or more. This is also the threshold that triggers a filing requirement for self-employed individuals, regardless of other income. Church employees have a different $108.28 threshold.
questions.tip: $400 threshold for SE tax and filing requirement. Much lower than standard filing threshold.

questions.question: Employer-provided group term life insurance is excludable from an employee's income up to:

options.B: $25,000 of coverage

questions.explanation: Employer-paid premiums for group term life insurance are excludable from the employee's income for coverage up to $50,000. The cost of coverage exceeding $50,000 (using IRS Table I rates, not actual cost) must be included in income and is subject to FICA taxes.
questions.tip: Group term life: first $50K coverage tax-free. Excess taxed using IRS Table I rates.

questions.question: Under the common law test, a worker is more likely an employee if:

options.A: The worker sets their own hours and provides their own tools
options.B: The business controls what work is done and how it is done
options.C: The worker has significant investment in equipment
options.D: The worker provides services to multiple clients

questions.explanation: Under the common law test, a worker is an employee if the business controls both what work is done AND how it is done. Key factors include: work schedule control, training provided, integration into operations, tools/equipment provided, and full-time requirement.
questions.tip: Control of 'what' and 'how' = employee. Independent contractors control their own methods.

questions.question: Form 1099-NEC must be filed for payments of nonemployee compensation totaling:

options.B: $400 or more

questions.explanation: Form 1099-NEC is required for payments of $600 or more to nonemployees for services. It replaced Box 7 of Form 1099-MISC starting in 2020. Due to recipients and IRS by January 31 (no automatic extension).
questions.tip: 1099-NEC = $600+ nonemployee compensation. Due January 31 (no extension). Replaced old 1099-MISC Box 7.

questions.question: The Work Opportunity Tax Credit (WOTC) benefits employers who hire:

options.B: Members of targeted groups facing employment barriers

questions.explanation: WOTC provides tax credits to employers hiring individuals from targeted groups facing employment barriers: veterans, SNAP recipients, ex-felons, designated community residents, vocational rehabilitation referrals, summer youth employees, TANF recipients, and long-term unemployment recipients.
questions.tip: WOTC = credit for hiring targeted groups. Pre-screen with Form 8850. Credit based on first-year wages.

questions.question: Household employers must pay FICA taxes if they pay a household employee:

options.B: $2,700 or more in a year (2024)

questions.explanation: For 2024, household employers must withhold and pay FICA taxes if they pay a household employee $2,700 or more during the year. This applies to workers such as nannies, housekeepers, and caregivers. FUTA applies if paying $1,000+ in any quarter.
questions.tip: Household employee threshold: $2,700 for FICA (2024), $1,000/quarter for FUTA. 'Nanny tax' rules.

questions.question: The flat federal withholding rate for supplemental wages (bonuses, commissions) up to $1 million is:
questions.explanation: Employers may withhold at a flat 22% rate on supplemental wages (bonuses, commissions, overtime, severance) up to $1 million. For supplemental wages over $1 million, the mandatory rate is 37%. Alternatively, employers can aggregate supplemental with regular wages and withhold at regular rates.
questions.tip: Supplemental wage flat rate: 22% up to $1M, 37% above $1M. Or can use aggregate method.

questions.question: The deduction for one-half of self-employment tax is claimed:

options.B: As an adjustment to income (above-the-line)
options.D: Only if the taxpayer has a net loss

questions.explanation: Self-employed individuals deduct half of self-employment tax as an adjustment to income (above-the-line), reducing AGI. This mirrors the fact that employees don't include the employer's share of FICA in their income. The deduction is available regardless of whether the taxpayer itemizes.
questions.tip: Half of SE tax = above-the-line deduction. Reduces AGI. Available whether itemizing or not.

questions.question: If an employer misclassifies an employee as an independent contractor without reasonable basis:

options.B: The employer owes 100% of the employee's share of FICA plus penalties
options.C: The employer owes additional amounts but less than full liability

questions.explanation: Without intentional disregard, the employer owes: 100% of employer's FICA, 20-40% of employee's FICA (not 100%), 1.5% of wages for income tax withholding, plus interest. With intentional disregard, full 100% liability plus penalties applies. Section 530 relief may provide protection.
questions.tip: Misclassification without intent: reduced rates (20-40% employee FICA). With intent: full liability + penalties.

questions.question: S corporation shareholder-employees can minimize overall taxes by:

options.A: Paying themselves no salary and taking only distributions
options.B: Paying reasonable compensation subject to FICA, with remaining profits as distributions not subject to FICA
options.D: Paying maximum salary to increase Social Security benefits

questions.explanation: S corp shareholder-employees must receive reasonable compensation (subject to FICA). However, profits distributed beyond reasonable salary are not subject to FICA/self-employment tax. The key is paying enough salary to satisfy IRS scrutiny while taking remaining profits as distributions.
questions.tip: S corp strategy: reasonable salary (subject to FICA) + distributions (no FICA). IRS watches for too-low salaries.

questions.question: An accountable expense reimbursement plan requires all of the following EXCEPT:

options.B: Substantiation of expenses within a reasonable time
options.C: Return of amounts in excess of substantiated expenses

questions.explanation: Accountable plans must have: (1) business connection, (2) adequate substantiation within reasonable time, and (3) return of excess reimbursements. No IRS approval is required. Reimbursements under accountable plans are excluded from income; nonaccountable plan payments are taxable wages.
questions.tip: Accountable plan: business connection + substantiation + return excess. No IRS approval needed. Tax-free reimbursements.

questions.question: Statutory employees (such as full-time life insurance salespeople) are treated as:

options.B: Employees for FICA but self-employed for income tax (can deduct expenses on Schedule C)

questions.explanation: Statutory employees are treated as employees for FICA purposes (employer withholds FICA) but can report income and deduct expenses on Schedule C like self-employed individuals. Categories include full-time life insurance salespeople, certain agent-drivers, home workers, and traveling salespeople.
questions.tip: Statutory employees: FICA like employees, Schedule C like contractors. Best of both worlds. Checkbox on W-2.

questions.question: The IRS Voluntary Classification Settlement Program (VCSP) allows employers to:

options.A: Classify all workers as contractors without consequence
options.B: Prospectively reclassify workers as employees with reduced liability for past periods

questions.explanation: VCSP allows eligible employers to reclassify workers as employees prospectively while paying only 10% of the employment tax liability for the most recent year, with no penalties or interest. Eligibility requires consistent treatment, filed 1099s, and no current audit.
questions.tip: VCSP: voluntary reclassification with 10% of one year's liability. No penalties/interest. Must not be under audit.

questions.question: Employer contributions to an employee's Health Savings Account (HSA) are:

options.B: Excluded from income and not subject to FICA
options.C: Excluded from income but subject to FICA

questions.explanation: Employer contributions to an employee's HSA are excluded from the employee's income AND not subject to FICA taxes (both employer and employee portions). This differs from most fringe benefits that are excluded from income but still subject to FICA. Employee contributions through payroll are also FICA-exempt.
questions.tip: HSA employer contributions: excluded from income AND no FICA. Triple tax advantage (also tax-free growth and qualified distributions).

questions.question: The failure to deposit penalty for employment taxes ranges from:
questions.explanation: Failure to deposit penalties are: 2% (1-5 days late), 5% (6-15 days late), 10% (16+ days late or within 10 days of first IRS notice), 15% (amounts still unpaid more than 10 days after first notice or day of notice of intent to levy). These are in addition to interest.
questions.tip: Deposit penalties escalate: 2% → 5% → 10% → 15% based on how late. Plus interest. EFTPS required for most employers.

questions.question: Rental income from real estate is generally:

options.B: Never subject to self-employment tax
options.C: Subject to SE tax only if the taxpayer is a real estate dealer or the rentals involve substantial services
options.D: Subject to SE tax only for LLCs

questions.explanation: Rental income is generally excluded from self-employment tax. However, SE tax applies if the taxpayer is a real estate dealer (selling property in the ordinary course of business) or provides substantial services with the rental (like a hotel). The exception for rentals is in IRC Section 1402(a)(1).
questions.tip: Rental income generally exempt from SE tax. Exception: real estate dealers and rentals with substantial services.

questions.question: A single-member LLC's self-employment tax treatment depends on:

options.B: Whether the LLC files Form 8832 to elect corporate taxation

questions.explanation: A single-member LLC is a disregarded entity by default - the owner reports income on Schedule C and pays SE tax on net earnings. If the LLC elects corporate taxation (Form 8832), SE tax doesn't apply - but the owner-employee must receive reasonable wages subject to FICA.
questions.tip: SMLLC default: Schedule C + SE tax. Elect S corp taxation: no SE tax but reasonable salary required.

questions.question: The employer credit for paid family and medical leave under Section 45S provides a credit of:

options.B: 12.5% to 25% of wages paid during leave, depending on the percentage of normal wages

questions.explanation: Section 45S provides a credit of 12.5% of wages paid for FMLA leave if the payment is at least 50% of normal wages, increasing up to 25% if payment equals 100% of normal wages. The employer must have a written policy and provide at least 2 weeks of paid leave.
questions.tip: Section 45S FMLA credit: 12.5-25% of wages based on pay rate. Need written policy and 2+ weeks paid leave.

questions.question: Employees who receive tips of $20 or more in a month must:

options.A: Report tips directly to the IRS
options.B: Report tips to their employer by the 10th of the following month
options.D: Report tips only if exceeding $600 annually

questions.explanation: Employees receiving $20 or more in tips in a month must report tips to their employer by the 10th of the following month. The employer then withholds income tax and the employee's share of FICA from wages. Employers owe FICA on reported tips and may qualify for the Section 45B tip credit.
questions.tip: Tips $20+/month: report to employer by 10th. Employer withholds taxes. Section 45B credit for employer FICA.

questions.question: U.S. citizens working abroad for a U.S. employer are generally:

options.B: Subject to U.S. FICA taxes unless a totalization agreement applies
options.C: Only subject to the foreign country's employment taxes

questions.explanation: U.S. citizens and resident aliens working for U.S. employers abroad remain subject to U.S. FICA taxes. Totalization agreements with certain countries allow workers to be covered by only one country's system, avoiding double taxation. The foreign earned income exclusion doesn't affect FICA.
questions.tip: U.S. expats: still subject to FICA unless totalization agreement. FEIE doesn't exclude from FICA.

questions.question: A limited partner's distributive share of partnership income is generally:

options.B: Exempt from self-employment tax (except guaranteed payments for services)
options.C: Subject to FICA instead of SE tax

questions.explanation: Limited partners are generally exempt from SE tax on their distributive share of partnership income under IRC 1402(a)(13). However, guaranteed payments to any partner for services are subject to SE tax. The treatment of LLC members as limited partners is uncertain and controversial.
questions.tip: Limited partner SE exemption: distributive share exempt, guaranteed payments for services taxable.

questions.question: Qualified small businesses can elect to apply up to $500,000 of R&D credit against:

options.B: FICA taxes (employer portion)
options.D: Both federal income tax and state taxes

questions.explanation: The PATH Act (expanded by Inflation Reduction Act) allows qualified small businesses (under $5 million gross receipts, no receipts for 5+ years prior) to elect to apply up to $500,000 of R&D credit against employer FICA taxes (Social Security portion), rather than income tax.
questions.tip: Startup R&D credit vs. payroll tax: up to $500K against employer SS. For companies with no/low income but high payroll.
